Award.AwardTitle: Spectroscopic Probes of Molecule Structure and Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Experimental Physical Chemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Patrick H. Vaccaro of Yale University, together with his graduate and undergraduate student researchers, will study the structure and properties of a number of gas-phase chemical systems. Included amongst these will be laser spectroscopic studies of the hydrogen-bond tunneling dynamics in tropolone and the low-barrier hydrogen bonding and conical intersections in ÃŸ-diketo enols. In addition, Prof. Vaccaro and his group will continue their pioneering efforts in developing ultrasensitive methods for measuring the optical activity (optical rotatory dispersion and electronic circular dichroism) in gas-phase chiral molecules, using cavity-ringdown techniques.

Hydrogen bonding is important in a number of contexts, including giving water its unique chemical and physical properties, as well as being a vital component of biomolecule interaction. Vaccaro's group will study the behavior of the hydrogen bond in a number of its guises. Vacarro's work in gas-phase chiroptical spectroscopy is providing theorists with important solvent-free measurements with which to compare with computer-based calculations of optical activity. Already, this has provided a number of important, non-intuitive, insights and will continue to do so. The students trained in the Vaccaro laboratory will be trained in modern methods of laser spectroscopy, and will be important additions to the technical workforce. Vaccaro's research group is majority female, and hence Prof. Vaccaro is contributing to an increase in the number of scientists in this particular underrepresented group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research conducted under the auspices of this NSF grant has endeavored to understand the origins of molecular behavior, as revealed by the systematic exploration of fundamental physical properties and chemical propensities. Laboratory experiments have exploited diverse forms of linear and nonlinear optical spectroscopy to interrogate the lowest lying (ground) and excited states of targeted molecular species, thereby elucidating the coupling among electronic and nuclear degrees of freedom that ultimately governs their structure and dynamics. When combined with detailed theoretical models, information gleaned from such work affords a trenchant glimpse of phenomena that permeate the entire fabric of chemistry and related fields of study, including proton transfer, hydrogen bonding, and chirality. Successful execution of these efforts has necessitated numerous technical innovations and conceptual advancements, many of which have application to problems of broader impact involving remote sensing, trace detection, and materials analysis.

Reactions involving the transfer of protons between distinct chemical moieties, as often mediated by the presence of weak intermolecular or intramolecular hydrogen bonds, are among the most prevalent of transformations in chemistry and biochemistry, being responsible for the bulk physiochemical properties displayed by liquid water as well as for the subtle mechanisms that regulate in vivo enzyme catalysis. An extensive body of work has established the basic paradigms that govern such processes; however, important questions regarding their manifestation and origin continue to emerge. Under NSF sponsorship, a variety of laser spectroscopic tools have been developed to elucidate the nature of elementary proton-transfer events that are classically forbidden yet occur with great alacrity owing to the action of quantum-mechanical tunneling phenomena. Special emphasis was placed on the structural and dynamical consequences of incipient hydrogen-bond formation in model organic compounds, as revealed by the marked dependence of tunneling-induced spectroscopic signatures on selective vibrational and/or electronic excitation, thereby unraveling the fundamental mechanisms that underlie analogous processes transpiring in substantially more complicated chemical and biochemical systems.

The multifaceted concept of chirality (or intrinsic handedness) permeates all aspects of modern science, ranging from the physics of elementary particles and galaxy formation to the structure and function of the macromolecular complexes responsible for life. Of particular importance is the stereochemistry (or three-dimensional arrangement) of organic molecules such as those targeted by the pharmaceutical industry, where the right and left forms can have profoundly different effects – one being therapeutic while the other is mutagenic, carcinogenic, or worse. Under the auspices of this NSF grant, novel spectroscopic probes of molecular chirality (based on chiroptical phenomena whereby chiral molecules interact specifically with chiral forms of light) have been developed and their putative utility as a means of discriminating absolute stereochemical configuration has been explored systematically. Aside from performing benchmark measurements under isolated-molecule conditions that alleviate extrinsic complications incurred from the surroundings (e.g., solvation), these efforts have examined various processes that strongly affect intrinsic chiroptical response, including solute-solvent coupling (environmental perturbations), conformational flexibility (large-amplitude nuclear motions), and vibrational dynamics (intrinsic molecular non-rigidity).
